awd_titl_txt: Simulating Spins with an Array of Single Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
General audience abstract:
Quantum mechanics is at the heart of countless scientific problems, from the detailed behavior of molecules to superconductivity to microelectronics to lasers.  The simplest quantum mechanical behavior has already been used to build the precise atomic clocks at the heart of our Global Positioning System, which underlies the smartphone maps that most Americans use for navigation.  The current project funds a study of more complex quantum behavior, where many quantum systems interact in a precisely controlled manner.  As moderately-sized interacting quantum systems are beyond the prediction power of even the world’s fastest supercomputers, such “quantum simulators” are thought to offer new insights that may advance chemistry, physics, medicine, and energy technology.  The systems developed here, based on individually controlled interacting molecules, will also strengthen American leadership in the world-wide pursuit of quantum technologies and train and prepare students for the quantum technology workforce.

Technical audience abstract:
Quantum simulation, where phase diagrams and dynamics of many-body quantum systems can be simulated directly by precisely controlled laboratory analogues, has generated much interest in the Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics (AMO) community. Platforms for quantum simulation abound and have already seen success in studying quantum magnetism, many-body localization, the Fermi-Hubbard model, and topological phases. Fully controlled systems of ultracold molecules, with their rich internal structure and long-range electric dipole interactions, have been proposed as candidates to add to these platforms in simulating the dynamics of spin systems, among many others. This project aims to create a quantum simulator of spin dynamics consisting of a configurable array of ultracold dipolar molecules, assembled atom by atom and held in individual optical tweezers. The work involves expanding full quantum state control of a single molecule to an array of molecules and tuning their inter-particle interactions by electric field and microwave control. Furthermore, a combination of optical tweezers and lattices to simultaneously reduce photon scattering while allowing uniform trapping potentials, high trapping frequencies, flexible geometries, and a fast repetition rate will be pursued.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project develops a fully controlled array of interacting ultracold molecules in optical tweezers for quantum simulations of spin systems. These molecules are prepared at temperatures near absolute zero. Initially, we demonstrated preparing an individual molecule in the internal molecular ground state and holding it in the motional ground state of an optical tweezer. During the grant, we successfully gained full control over rotational and nuclear spin projection states and demonstrated coherent exchange of rotational energy between adjacent molecules via long-range dipole-dipole interactions. These interactions can be used for entanglement and quantum logic gates. The rotational degree of freedom serves as pseudo-spins, and these interactions will be scaled for larger system to simulate interacting quantum spins.

Intellectual Merit:

We made significant progress in ultracold molecule manipulation and demonstrated their utility as pseudo-spins for entanglement and quantum logic gates. These advancements lay the foundation for future research in quantum computing, quantum simulation, and quantum sensors.

  1. Scaling Up the System and Optimizing Molecule Production
    Our goal was to scale up the experimental platform to create dense arrays of NaCs molecules in the rovibrational ground state. We successfully implemented a reconfigurable array of optical tweezers, achieving high-fidelity atom placement (~95% accuracy). We improved two-photon transfer efficiency to ~75% by selecting a narrower linewidth intermediate state, a key step for scaling molecule production.
  2. Improving Molecular Coherence and Interaction Control
    We enhanced the coherence of molecular rotational states by developing a "magic ellipticity" polarization scheme, reducing light shifts and increasing coherence time by over two orders of magnitude. This allowed the observation of coherent rotational energy exchange between neighboring molecules and the preparation of Bell states with 94% fidelity in 1 ms.
  3. Advanced Control of Molecule-Molecule Interactions
    We further advanced molecule-molecule interaction control using site-specific microwave control and dynamical decoupling. This allowed us to dynamically vary dipole-dipole interactions, localizing rotational excitations in individual molecules. These advances enabled the first quantum logic gates with trapped molecules, a key step toward molecular quantum information processors.
  4. Enhanced Detection and Measurement Capabilities
    We developed techniques for multi-state readout of molecules and across multiple sites. This method dissociates molecules into atoms and detects atomic fluorescence in a single experimental cycle.

Broader Impacts:

This research impacts quantum technologies, materials science, and education.

  1. Advancing Quantum Technologies
    The ability to control ultracold molecules is critical for next-generation quantum technologies. Our work improves molecular coherence, enabling high-fidelity entanglement and simulating complex quantum systems, such as molecular materials and spin networks, which are challenging for classical computation.

 

  1. Training the Next Generation of Quantum Scientists and Accelerating Progress in Other Labs
    The project provided advanced training for graduate students and postdocs in ultracold molecule manipulation and quantum control. Our methodology, techniques, schemes, and science advances have directly facilitated and benefited other research groups: including Simon Cornish (Durham, UK), John Doyle (Harvard), Lawrence Cheuk (Princeton), Jonathan Hood (Purdue) who are working on similar optical tweezer platforms with different molecular species, as well as Sebastian Will (Columbia) who works on the exact same molecular species while developing a bulk gas platform.

Conclusion:

This project has significantly advanced ultracold molecular physics, improving molecule control for quantum technologies. Through scalable optical tweezer arrays, enhanced molecule production, and better molecular coherence, as well as the demonstration of a quantum logic gate with trapped molecules, we have set the stage for experiments with large molecular arrays. Our work not only pushes scientific boundaries but also contributes to quantum technologies with wide-reaching applications in computing, sensing, and quantum simulation.
